sections.title: The Blessings of a Good Wife

verses.text: Blessed is the husband of a good wife; the number of his days will be doubled.
verses.comment: A virtuous spouse is depicted as a blessing that brings longevity and happiness, reflecting the high value placed upon marriage as ordained by God. The doubling of days recalls the Old Testament promise of long life through divine favor (cf. Ex. 20:12).
verses.sectionHeader: The Blessings of a Good Wife

verses.text: A loyal wife rejoices her husband, and he will finish his years in peace.
verses.comment: Faithful companionship is connected with peace and the completion of one's life in tranquility, echoing biblical virtue centered in harmony and fidelity in the household.

verses.text: A good wife is a great blessing; she will be granted among the blessings of the man who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: Here, the connection between wisdom, goodness, and the fear of God is made clear, rooting marriage in reverence before the Lord (cf. Ps. 128:1-3).

verses.text: Whether rich or poor, his heart is cheerful, and at all times his face is bright.
verses.comment: Material status does not affect true joy found in faithful marital love; this highlights the spiritual fruits of sacramental union, independent of worldly success.

verses.text: There are three things that make my heart afraid, and a fourth that I dread: slander in a city, the gathering of people, false accusation—all are worse than death.
verses.comment: Public dishonor and false accusations are presented as causes of great fear, emphasizing the biblical theme of the destructive power of the tongue and social discord (cf. Jas. 3:6).

verses.text: But there is pain in heart and grief: a wife who is jealous of another woman.
verses.comment: Jealousy in marriage disrupts peace, linking interior suffering to broken relationships. The concept of jealousy here has roots in Old Testament law governing marital fidelity.

verses.text: A wicked wife is a heavy burden to her husband; he who would grab hold of her is like grasping a scorpion.
verses.comment: Marital discord is described in sharp imagery, warning against the consequences of choosing foolishly. The symbolic use of ‘scorpion’ alludes to pain and danger, reminiscent of biblical warnings (cf. Ez. 2:6).

verses.text: A drunken wife causes great anger; she will not hide her shame.
verses.comment: Drunkenness in the household is viewed as a source of disgrace, highlighting the virtue of self-control and moderation as essential elements in godly living.

verses.text: The indecent wife will be recognized by her haughty look and her eyelids.
verses.comment: Physical demeanor is equated here with inward vice. Expressions and gestures are signs of inward attitudes, connecting body and soul in biblical anthropology.

verses.text: Keep a strict watch over a headstrong daughter, lest she make you a laughing-stock to your enemies, a talk in the city, and an object of derision among the people, and shame you before the assembly.
verses.comment: Parental responsibility is emphasized; neglect leads to dishonor both privately and publicly. The theme of disciplining children for communal well-being is prominent in wisdom literature.

verses.text: Do not let her run loose in her youth, and do not overlook her faults.
verses.comment: Early discipline protects children from harmful choices, advocating vigilant parenting as a preventive for future shame and sin.

verses.text: If your daughter is willful, be watchful, lest she make you a laughing-stock; do not let her flirt with men, or walk where women gather.
verses.comment: Guarding against inappropriate behavior maintains family honor. Wisdom tradition warns against licentiousness, which can break both familial and communal bonds.

verses.text: A wife’s charm delights her husband, and her skill puts flesh on his bones.
verses.comment: Physical and spiritual nourishment are united—the wife’s virtues are life-giving. The artistry of the home and a woman’s wisdom foster well-being.

verses.text: A silent wife is a gift from the Lord, and nothing is as precious as her self-discipline.
verses.comment: Silence is not merely absence of speech but signifies wisdom, restraint, and grace—a deeply spiritual quality praised in biblical literature as a reflection of the soul’s union with God.

verses.text: A modest wife is grace upon grace; no scale can measure the worth of a chaste soul.
verses.comment: The language of ‘grace upon grace’ evokes the superabundance of spiritual blessings. Chastity is esteemed as priceless, anticipating the Christian call to imitate Christ’s purity (cf. Jn. 1:16).

verses.text: Like the sun rising over the Lord’s heights is the beauty of a good wife in a well-ordered house.
verses.comment: Imagery of the sun points toward both physical radiance and spiritual illumination. A ‘well-ordered house’ recalls the ordered harmony of God’s creation and the household as a microcosm of the Church.

verses.text: Like a shining lamp on a holy lampstand is a beautiful face on mature shoulders.
verses.comment: The lampstand metaphor is often used to evoke holiness and witness. Outer beauty is best displayed when joined with inner dignity, reflecting the structure and order of sacred worship.

verses.text: Gold pillars on silver bases are the sturdy legs and steady feet of a modest woman.
verses.comment: This architectural imagery connotes strength and enduring value. Modesty and virtue are presented as a foundation for lasting beauty in God’s design.

verses.text: My child, keep sound the bloom of your youth, and do not give your strength to strangers.
verses.comment: The admonition to preserve the bloom of youth and not give one's strength to strangers reflects ancient concerns for chastity and fidelity, warning against sexual promiscuity and the dissipation of one's vitality (cf. Proverbs 5:9-10).

verses.text: Seek a fertile field within the whole plain, and sow it with your own seed, trusting in your fine stock.
verses.comment: This metaphor of sowing in a fertile field suggests investing in legitimate relationships and family life, emphasizing responsibility and trust in one's own lineage.

verses.text: So your offspring will prosper, and, having confidence in their good descent, will grow great.
verses.comment: Prosperity and growth of offspring are seen as blessings stemming from faithful choices, with 'good descent' highlighting the importance of family reputation and moral legacy (cf. Psalm 112:2).

verses.text: A prostitute is regarded as spittle, and a married woman as a tower of death to her lovers.
verses.comment: The proverb contrasts the fleeting, degrading reputation of prostitution with the formidable, dangerous consequences of adultery with a married woman, underscoring the dangers of sexual sin (cf. Proverbs 6:32).

verses.text: A godless wife is given as a portion to a lawless man, but a pious wife is given to the man who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: This verse reflects the ancient Jewish view that spouses are divinely matched, with character—whether good or evil—determining the nature of such unions (cf. Proverbs 19:14).

verses.text: A shameless woman constantly acts disgracefully, but a modest daughter will even be embarrassed before her husband.
verses.comment: The contrast between shameless and modest women underscores the value of virtue and self-restraint, commonly upheld in ancient wisdom literature.

verses.text: A headstrong wife is regarded as a dog, but one who has a sense of shame will fear the Lord.
verses.comment: Comparing a headstrong wife to a dog indicates ancient views associating stubbornness with disorder, while linking modesty with devotional reverence and piety (cf. Proverbs 31:30).

verses.text: A wife honoring her husband will seem wise to all, but if she dishonors him in her pride she will be known to all as ungodly. Happy is the husband of a good wife; for the number of his years will be doubled.
verses.comment: This verse stresses the social and spiritual benefits of a harmonious marriage, with the good wife's public respect and her husband's well-being reflecting wisdom literature's theme of the virtuous woman (cf. Proverbs 31:10-12).

verses.text: A loud-voiced and garrulous wife is like a trumpet sounding the charge, and every person like this lives in the anarchy of war.
verses.comment: A contentious or disruptive wife is likened to a battle trumpet, illustrating the destructive potential of domestic strife and verbal discord (cf. Proverbs 21:9).

verses.text: At two things my heart is grieved, and because of a third anger comes over me: a warrior in want through poverty, intelligent men who are treated contemptuously, and a man who turns back from righteousness to sin—the Lord will prepare him for the sword!
verses.comment: The author laments injustice: poverty among warriors (who should be honored), contempt for the wise, and apostasy, with God's judgment reserved for those who turn from righteousness (cf. Ezekiel 18:24).

verses.text: A merchant can hardly keep from wrongdoing, nor is a tradesman innocent of sin.
verses.comment: This reflection acknowledges the moral challenges inherent in commerce, suggesting that the temptations of trade make absolute innocence difficult, echoing themes found in Proverbs 11:1 and 1 Timothy 6:9.
